node.text: @therealrebeccakingcrews yes ma’am, of course I did. I’m not deriding the message- I think the delivery was TERRIBLE. By the way - we met years ago at Gerrish & have nothing but respect for you & your husband

@therealrebeccakingcrews 👏 I actually commented that earlier. A lot to seem to be hung up on tthe sexual abuse or abuse against women aspect of it, but nobody is looking at the fact that it also spoke of boys bullying one another and children hurting one another. It’s a beautiful commercial, and I don’t understand why anyone can be offended by it. It’s not saying that all men are read this, but rather than most men are good and they need to hold those slim few accountable and let the younger ones see that example.

Repost from my husband @terrycrews. If this add offends you, check your filter. Ladies I’d like to hear your thoughts, brothers I really need you to share yours! Do you think this ad paints ALL men as toxic?  #Repost @terrycrews with @get_repost
・・・
“Boys will be boys” is not an excuse. It’s time men hold other men accountable. Proud to lend my voice to help @gillette share this message - Head to my story or to thebestmencanbe.org today to learn more. #TheBestMenCanBe #gillettepartner

I wouldn’t say that all men are bad, to me it means is that God isn’t in the center of their lives. There are quality men out there who will respect women it’s where God wants to use us in the right time and place in work and situation where he leads by example.

Men do need to hold other men accountable. 👏 
My husband had a very disturbing moment with a work colleague. I wanted to personally seek this dorkwad out and give him a piece of my mind but thankfully my husband was able to say what was needed. Praising our men is a valid need but this ad is powerful and I find it’s needed. Hopefully others can set aside their offense and take away what the message is. It’s a call to action... not a reprimand. Note good men are behind this ad. 🤔

No I don’t think it paints all men as toxic . It simply doesn’t deny history when inappropriate behaviour towards women was the norm.  What it’s saying now is that it needs to stay in the past. Let men check other men . Let’s face it men will probably listen to other men quicker than they would women. But it’s also asking today’s men to be the role models to tomorrow’s men. That way the “ norm” will be respect for women and men . Mostly though this ad is trying to sell a product and the fact that everyone is discussing it means it’s probably working 😊

This ad is brilliant.  And thank god for your husband.  His voice has already made an incredible impact.  I gave a copy of his book to all the young men in my life.  I’m so grateful for the men who are stepping up.
@kingdombuilders24 #TEAMCREWS
My hero @terrycrews you were the only man who spoke up for all women!!! You are on your assignment. Blessings to you and your family @therealrebeccakingcrews 💞👏🏿👏🏿👏🏿👏🏿🎤🕺🏾
Paint all men as toxic? Not at all. Just those who lack respect & self control.
@anncargal  But did you REALLY watch it?

@therealrebeccakingcrews yes ma’am, of course I did. I’m not deriding the message- I think the delivery was TERRIBLE. By the way - we met years ago at Gerrish & have nothing but respect for you & your husband

@therealrebeccakingcrews 👏 I actually commented that earlier. A lot to seem to be hung up on tthe sexual abuse or abuse against women aspect of it, but nobody is looking at the fact that it also spoke of boys bullying one another and children hurting one another. It’s a beautiful commercial, and I don’t understand why anyone can be offended by it. It’s not saying that all men are read this, but rather than most men are good and they need to hold those slim few accountable and let the younger ones see that example.
I respect you both- but this ad paints masculinity with a wide and NEGATIVE brush.  Virtue signaling at its best. Women’s ads: embrace yourself just as you are. Men’s ads: you’re a rapist
Amen! This is so long over due! Thank you @terrycrews ?
love it!
No, not all men at all. Just the ones that need to do better. If you’re a decent man to begin with, this ad likely wouldn’t offend you. 🤷🏽‍♀️

Not all men but as we all know there are men that feel entitled to touch and say whatever they want!! Boys need to see that this is not appropriate behavior so they don’t replicate it!! #timesup #teamcrews ⌛️🙏🏾

He had specifically says most men are good, but remember the only thing necessary for evil to prosper is for good men to do nothing. It seems that they are telling the good man to speak up and challenge their comrades and colleagues when their behavior is inappropriate.

In my early 20's oooh the stuff the guys would say and do. So disgusting, even when I reported someone one day we had a meeting with HR and I told him to his face how would you feel if someone did what you're doing to me to your mom or sister. He said yeah you're right.... walked to our desks after the meeting and he said some more inappropriate mess.... so I reported him again. They moved me to the other side of the office and did nothing to him.

@therealrebeccakingcrews I agree that boys will be boys is no excuse. There for far too long men that have been abused and neglected as boys grow up and do damage to others. Afraid to stand and give it to God because they associate God as a man they can not trust. Some hold resentment for the father that left or hurt them. Fear is the enemy’s tool along with shame to keep hurts hidden to separate us from healing ,treatment,and the real love that heals from Jesus. I know that God is pleased with transparency that is a testimony to how God can heal and defeat fear and shame. This is what is needed God Bless You Both in Jesus name abundantly 💋💞💞💞

I was absolutely blown away when I heard that @terrycrews was not only speaking out, but was THE FACE of men affected by the disgusting behaviors of “The Powers that be” in Hollywood. Terry is the epitome of what a man and husband should be (not to mention an amazing actor) If this happened to him, it’s happened to lots of other men, but for whatever reason they have not spoken about it or are afraid to. He risked everything to take a stand and speak on what happened to him knowing that it was for a cause so much bigger than just him. Absolutely selfless. So much love and respect to him and to you as his wife, always standing firm by his side. God bless both of you❤️❤️
@parisafitzhenley Yessssssss, I so agree. Preach it Sister💗

I love this ad. It reminds me of the wonderful men I know who do step up to defend and support women — and each other. It warms my heart to see men facing their shortcomings and looking to improve. I’d personally love to see something like this where women support each other in being kinder to themselves. Each gender expression has its general strengths and weaknesses. I felt like this ad focused on men’s strengths to help curb their weaknesses. Very here for it.

In 2016, I was fired from a corporate company that used to ignore not only all the sexual comments made to the woman in the company (including me), but I also had to keep quiet when I’d hear racist comments about Hispanics, (I am Latina) as well. I wanted to sue but couldn’t afford a lawyer at the time.  I was wrongfully terminated and was threatened if I  didn’t sign an agreement to keep quiet and not sue them. It’s ridiculous what people get away with. Enough is enough!

Even as a psychologist, and someone who’s experienced sexual abuse as a child, it’s difficult to say.

I do not see all men this way. And it’s almost like breathing a sigh of relief to see other men holding each other accountable. It’s kind of like “ok breathe, there are more people on the side of right”. It felt like we didn’t have that before. It’s one of the reasons we as women/girls stay silent. As a girl of 9, I questioned the morality of what had happened to me, but figured his behaviour would be passed off as “men being men” and that I would end up being the one in trouble.
When I finally told someone, you know what their response was? “You sure he wasn’t just playing? You know what his sense of humour is like!” I felt so betrayed at that point.

And now I’m at an age where I’m thinking how great it would be to have children, I’m terrified for them already. 
Does anyone here remember the Pepe Le Pew children’s cartoon? The skunk that would sexually harass the females skunks, even after receiving very firm “No!” from them? How that cartoon ever came to be is just astounding to me. 
A parent can do an amazing job raising their boys, but as they get older it becomes harder to maintain the values you taught them if they conflict with their friends’ attitudes. Out driving around and driving past a young woman hearing one of them call “Dibbs!” on the woman like she’s nothing more than an object. As a parent at that stage you can only hope your values and morals you instilled in them as a child hold up against the toxic masculinity that sadly still exists.

I do not think this ad paints all men as toxic. Terry has been an incredible voice in this fight. I do not believe for one second that Terry would lend his words to an ad campaign he felt was unjust towards men as a whole.

For men complaining it paints you in a negative light, spare a moment to think about all the girls and women who were painted in a negative light just for sharing their abuse story, and being told it’s “just men being men.”
I think people haven’t watched it closely enough. It talks about boys bullying boys too, Indy’s no just about how they should treat females.
